intro: Gilia inconspicua var. dentiflora, commonly known as the toothed gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is characterized by its slender stems and clusters of small, showy flowers. The leaves are alternate, ovate, and often have serrated edges, contributing to its common name. The flowers typically bloom in shades of pink to purple and are pollinated by insects. This plant thrives in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and chaparral.
